instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short on Vcore
threads.message: I'm to the point where I don't even want to touch these boards anymore when I measure a short on vcore (0.5Î© in this case.) I can't remember a time when it wasn't the CPU. Is there anything else I should look for before letting this go? The board looks mostly clean, but the customer reported it as a spill. <RESISTOR>R7202</RESISTOR> looks like it probably got hit. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING</SIGNAL> wasn't shorted. Board is cycling. <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> is cycling. Fan will occasionally spin up when power is applied.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short on Vcore
threads.message: yeah 0.5 is too low on CPU, RIP.
